Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Advanced Optical Disdrometer for Precipitation Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Disdrometer is an instrument that is typically used for measurement of precipitation microphysical characteristics such as raindrop/snow size distributions, shapes, and fall velocities as well as identification of precipitation type (e.g. snow, hail, rain). Disdrometers are used in various applications related to geophysical sciences (e.g. meteorology, atmospheric sciences, hydrology) and engineering (e.g. civil engineering, environmental engineering). Potential user segments for disdrometers include federal agencies and similar international agencies, research institutes, universities, airports, and weather stations. Majority of the disdrometer systems are either optical or impact type disdrometers, which are associated with various instrumental measurement artifacts. Although optical disdrometers have a much greater potential for commercial success over other disdrometer types, this potential has been mainly hampered due to measurement accuracy issues related to the optical depth of field.

This team has developed the Advanced Optical Disdrometer (AOD) with high-speed image recording capability. The high-speed imaging capability of the AOD provides an ability to monitor the actual shapes and motions of the hydrometeors. Using image processing, the AOD provides information on the shapes (e.g. diameter, vertical to horizontal axis ratio, canting angles) and motions (e.g. fall velocity, acceleration) of hydrometeors with high accuracy. There are two critical innovative components of the proposed system: volume confinement principle and the high-speed (up to 1000 frames per second) image recording capability. Volume confinement principle overcomes the measurement accuracy issues that are pertinent to optical disdrometers and the high-speed image recording provides an ability to monitor the actual shapes and motions of the particles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF I-Corps project was to explore commercialization opportunities for a new optical-type disdrometer that is called as the High-speed Optical Disdrometer (HOD).  Disdrometer is an instrument that is typically used for measurement of precipitation microphysical characteristics such as hydrometeor (e.g. raindrop, snowflake) size distributions, shapes, and fall velocities as well as identification of precipitation type (e.g. snow, hail, rain).  The HOD has been developed as part of the NSF Awards # AGS – 1144846 & 1612681 to investigate rainfall microphysics.  The main components of this NSF I-Corps efforts were: (i) to conduct a commercialization feasibility research for this novel technology, including identification of the mainstream commercial applications for it and its by-products, (ii) to improve and modify the developed system to address the needs of the identified potential customers and market(s), and (iii) to establish a roadmap to successfully commercialize the instrument.

The project team (the Principal Investigator, Entrepreneurial Lead, and Mentor) participated in a 7-weeks long I-Corps cohort training and activities.  During this 7-weeks timeframe, the team received intense training and guidance on lean startup methodologies with applications to the HOD technology.  The team conducted over 100 interviews with potential customers, partners, and leaders who oversee future research and technology directions that are relevant to the HOD (e.g. program managers in different agencies and organizations).  These interviews led to the identification of new applications and needs for the HOD, and development of a business model.  After the 7-week cohort activities, the team continued introducing the HOD, interviewing a large number of potential customers/users of the HOD, and developing/improving the HOD technology based upon interviews with the potential customers/users. 

The I-Corps activities showed that, among various potential applications of the HOD and its by-products, two of the applications, precipitation type identification and accurate and detailed measurements of hydrometeor characteristics, have significant commercial potential.  Precipitation type identification has important applications in transportation activities (e.g. airport and road operations) and measurement of hydrometeor characteristics has important research applications in a variety of disciplines (e.g. meteorology, hydrology).  The I-Corps activities showed that extensive resources and experience are needed to deliver a viable commercial product based upon this new technology in a timely manner.  For example, development of a commercial product that can withstand a wide variety of environmental conditions, testing and approval processes in aviation applications (a major portion of the identified potential market) are a few of the long and challenging processes.  The existing companies that produce weather monitoring instruments typically have a wealth of experience in mechanical designs for ruggedizing such systems, the financial power to sustain such extended periods of testing before generating revenues through sales of these systems, and established sales channels for the very challenging customer segments in the transportation applications.  Therefore, the team decided to commercialize the HOD through these weather instrumentation companies, and the HOD technology has been introduced to these companies. 

The I-Corps project was completed successfully with significant broader impacts.  The project provided valuable training and professional development opportunities to the team members and to the undergraduate and graduate students that were involved in relevant efforts.  New applications of this technology and a roadmap for the technology development and commercialization efforts for this new technology were identified.  The HOD has already started impacting the relevant research fields by providing measurement capabilities for precipitation microphysical quantities that could not be measured by commercially available instruments (e.g. raindrop oscillations) and to provide improved measurement accuracies.  For example, the HOD measurements provided the first-time observations of raindrop collisions and frequency of collisions in rainfall events, which has important applications in modeling raindrop size distribution, a quantity that has a variety of applications (e.g. radar rainfall retrievals, soil erosion, telecommunication) ranging in different disciplines.  As such, the scientific and societal impacts of the HOD are expected to be significant and grow in years to come.
